facts.text: Baga Rao, an excise contractor, had separated from his brothers and partitioned family lands; differences led to arbitration proceedings a few months earlier which did not satisfy Baga Rao.
On Saturday previous to December 26, 1955, quarrel between Baga Rao and Lingarao and Narsingrao in field belonging to Baga Rao.
Parties reside in village Kollamaddi, taluk Sircilla, district Karimnagar.

At about 7 a.m. on December 26, 1955, Baga Rao proceeding from village towards Nirmal; accused lying in wait, appellant (Narayan Rao) fell upon him with knife (M.O.13); other accused (Lingarao, Narsingrao, Mahboob Ali) caught hold; appellant inflicted several injuries including fatal ones in neck and abdomen.
PW1 (Dharmiah, father's brother of appellant) saw most of occurrence, hid in hut out of fear.
PW2 (Ramchander Rao, 12-year-old boy, student, distantly related to Baga Rao) saw whole occurrence from few yards; claimed Baga Rao as maternal uncle but PW6 (wife) said distantly related.

Chatriah (father of deceased, DW1, aged 85) disclaimed relation with PW2, related to PW1 (full brother); defence suggested PW1 and son murdered Baga Rao and implicated accused, rejected as not put earlier.
DW2 (son-in-law of PW1) testified rivalry between PW1 and accused over land purchase; evidence rejected as vague.
PW1 informed Gopal Rao (PW8, Police Patel) at 11 a.m. Dec 26; FIR drawn naming all four accused, sent to Gambhiraopet station.

Sub-Inspector (PW11) to spot, prepared inquest report: throat cut, injuries on stomach, thigh, left hand; panchas (Lachmayya, Ramayya PW10) present; recorded what seen/heard including substance of PW1 and PW2 statements.
Post-mortem Dec 27: confirmed injuries, neck wound cut trachea, oesophagus, jugular vein.
Panchnama (Ex P-5) same day, signed by panchas and purporting by accused: complete confession by all accused; irregular.
Blood-stained garments from accused houses, blood-stained knife near body identified as appellant's, all human blood per chemical examiner.
Jan 10-11, 1956: Magistrate recorded full statements of PW1 Ramchander Rao and PW2 Dharmiah under s.164 CrPC.
Police report u/s 173 CrPC by IO on Jan 11, 1956, before Magistrate Jan 12: complete prosecution case, witness list.
Magistrate examined IO as W1, eye-witnesses as PW2-3, medical as PW4 ~Feb 15, 1956.
Feb 16, 1956: Magistrate questioned accused in detail, put evidence to them; denied complicity, alleged enmity.
Magistrate framed charges: s.302 IPC vs appellant; s.302 r/w 34,109 vs others; questioned accused again.
No grievance before Magistrate or Sessions Judge re non-compliance s.173(4); cross-exam lengthy, referred to police records.
Sessions Judge convicted appellant u/s 302 IPC, death; others life; High Court affirmed on appeal/reference Nov 20, 1956.
Ground of non-compliance ss.173,207A first raised in High Court appeal memo.
High Court: accused got copies in Sessions before witness statements; no grievance of short time or adjournment request; no prejudice.

legal_issues.text: Whether and, if so, how far non-compliance with ss.173(4) and 207A(3) CrPC affected legality of proceedings and trial resulting in conviction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of ss.173(4) and 207A(3) CrPC not complied with; omission vitiates entire proceedings and trial ipso facto, rendering them null and void; fresh trial necessary irrespective of prejudice.

respondent_arguments.text: Omission conceded but not sufficient to vitiate trial unless accused showed prejudice; accused got copies in Sessions Court before witness statements; no grievance of short time or request for adjournment.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution evidence (PW1, PW2 eye-witnesses, recoveries, blood-stained articles) reliable; no reason to differ from lower courts on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ground for interference on merits.

court_reasoning.text: ss.173(4) and 207A(3) introduced to simplify commitment and safeguard accused by furnishing documents; Magistrate duty-bound to ensure compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions directory, not mandatory; 'shall' not imperative as omission should not vitiate trial.

court_reasoning.text: Non-compliance irregularity curable u/s 537 CrPC unless prejudice shown; no prejudice here as straightforward case, full cross-exam, early FIR naming accused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No attempt before SC to show prejudice.

court_reasoning.text: Cited precedents: Abdul Rahman (s.360 irregularity cured); Pulukuri Kotayya (s.162 breach cured u/s 537); distinguished N.A. Subramania (trial not substantially per Code).

holdings.text: Non-compliance with ss.173(4) and 207A(3) CrPC is directory irregularity curable u/s 537 unless prejudice shown; no prejudice, trial valid.

precedents_cited.relevance: Failure to comply with s.360 CrPC cured by ss.535,537.
Breach of s.162 cured u/s 537 if trial substantially per Code.
Trial bad if not conducted in manner prescribed by Code.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges framed: s.302 vs appellant; s.302 r/w 34,109 vs others.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Non-compliance with 173(4),207A(3) held directory, curable u/s 537; others procedural.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction and death sentence of appellant under s.302 IPC affirmed; no interference with lower courts' findings on merits or procedural irregularity.

key_quotes.text: "The word 'shall' occurring both in sub-s. 4 of s. 173 and sub-s. 3 of s. 207A is not mandatory but only directory"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nature of provisions.

key_quotes.text: "if the trial is conducted substantially in the manner prescribed by the Code, but some irregularity occurs... the irregularity can be cured under s. 537"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts Pulukuri Kotayya on curability of irregularities.
